snippet: Use of brominated vegetable oil in foods, like fruit-flavored sodas, has long been allowed by federal regulators, but consumers have raised new concerns about the ingredient.
abstract: Use of brominated vegetable oil in foods and fruit-flavored sodas has long been allowed by federal regulators, but consumers have raised new concerns about ingredient, which is found in 10 percent of drinks sold in United States; European Union has long banned substance, which contains bromine, element found in brominated flame retardants, from foods and Japan has moved to do the same.
lead_paragraph: Use of brominated vegetable oil in foods, like fruit-flavored sodas, has long been allowed by federal regulators, but consumers have raised new concerns about the ingredient.

headline.seo: Another Look at a Drink Ingredient, Brominated Vegetable Oil
